controller

Class AbstractListSubController<E>

  • java.lang.Object
    • controller.AbstractListSubController<E>
  • Type Parameters:
    E - The type of the elements contained in the DefaultListModel managed by this controller.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    SubController

    public abstract class AbstractListSubController<E>
extends java.lang.Object
implements SubController
    An abstract implementation of a sub-controller that updates a JList's model based on the events passed to it by the master-controller.

    This controller also serves to allow a greater level of abstraction for managing ListModels through its typeParam field. Whether the model is set via the constructor or the setModel() method, it must be accompanied by a Class object of the same generic type. This allows for the generic type of the ListModel to be remembered at runtime, despite the type erasure that occurs. This allows the ListModel to be abstractly handled by a third class (with an implementation of this class serving as an intermediary layer) without the third class needing to know the type of objects accepted by the list, as the typeParam field allows for type checks to occur during runtime.

    Implementations of this class should feel free to create wrapper methods around existing DefaultListModel methods with a similar signature, as this conforms with the goal of this class to serve as a tool for greater abstraction of interactions with ListModels. NOTE: Such methods may need to be declared as generic methods, either in an implementation of this class or in a third class interacting with this one.

    If an implementation of this class is instantiated and a model is not set, it will be unable to perform any of its functions. While a no-argument constructor is provided, if it is used it is extremely important that a model be set using the setPropertyModel() method before attempting to invoke any actionable methods on this controller.

    Implementations of this class should only concern themselves with managing the model, and not worry about the view or other parts of the program, which are handled by the "master-controller".

    For more information on how sub-controllers are meant to behave, and their relationship with master-controllers, see the documentation for the SubController interface and the AbstractMasterController class.
    Version:
    2.0
    Author:
    Craig

      • getModel

        public javax.swing.DefaultListModel<E> getModel()
        Returns the model this controller is managing. If no model has been set, it will return a null value.
        Returns:
        the model this controller is managing, or null if none has been set.

      • getTypeParam

        public java.lang.Class<E> getTypeParam()
        Returns a Class object that defines the generic type of the elements contained in the ListModel. If no model has been set, it returns null.
        Returns:
        the generic type of the elements contained in the ListModel, or null if no model has been set.
